p: Ceriporia lacerata is a white-rot fungus first isolated as a new species from white-rotted wood in Japan [ 22]. Till 2006, only four other reports published about it, referring to its taxonomy, genetics or decomposition [ 23- 25]. Since 2007, C. lacerata has been more widely researched on its clinical significance, wood-decaying effect, metal tolerance and sorption potential and some other characteristics [ 26- 30]. Kim et al. [ 31] found that the cadmium(II) removal rates by C. lacerata in stationary and shaking cultures were about 7% and 11%, respectively. However, there is so limited information yet available on this species that its other properties need further study. The objectives of this work were to verify the capacity of dead C. lacerata in copper(II) removal under batch conditions, to determine the influences of parameters involved, and to simulate the adsorptive equilibrium and kinetics.
